column1: The instrument consists of two permanent horseshoe magnets
column2: fixed parallel with each other and an inch apart. A very thin spool or bobbin of insulated wire is suspended
column3: like the pendulum of a clock
column5: in such a manner that the bobbin hangs just in front of the four poles. A counterpoise is fixed at the top of the pendulum bar
column6: which permits the adjusting of the antagonistic forces represented by the action of the swinging bobbin
column8: which are insulated from the mass
column9: and which form one electrode of the local or annunciator circuit
column10: while the pendulum bar forms the other.It will be easily understood that as the bobbin hangs freely in the center of a very strong magnetic field (formed by the four poles of the two permanent magnets)
column11: the slightest current sent through the bobbin will cause the bobbin to be attracted from one direction
column12: while it will be repelled from the other
column13: according to the polarity of the current transmitted.
